interlinear-text.item: GSK [Dressage des oiseaux pour la chasse] [3]

phrase.item: First we watch for a falcon or a Merlin (small species of falcon) to land on a tree.
The falcon always turns his head towards Mecca.
Once we see that he is calm and that he hasn't flown away up until the evening, not far away, a bit ahead, we light a fire to blind him.
He watches the fire for the whole time and we throw a slip knot on him.
The slip knot is made like so: on a long stick we attach a knot made of horsehair; on one side we fix the knot to the stick.
At the middle of the loop we fix a small piece of cotton.
The merlin or the falcom strikes it with its beak and we pass the knot over its head.
When the knot has descended on its head it sets off and strangles itself.
Next we pull it over.
Once we've pulled it over, we envelop it in a cloth so that it doesn't break its wings.
Then we take the bird and we sew the eyes: we only sew one side of its eyelids with silk.
On both sides we leave a long thread at the end from which we make knots .
It sees a little bit.
When it is captured, we keep it up for two days so that it doesn't fall asleep, i.e. we don't let it sleep so that he gets used to human's scent, so that he becomes tame.
Then we put a leash on its foot and we attach it to a wooden perch, we place him on the perch so that he doesn't fly away.
For as long as we don't open its eyes its eyes, we bring meat near his beak and when he is hungry he pecks and eats.
When he has become accustomed to humans, we open his eyes.
Then in the house we step back and we show him meat our hand.We call: "Ma! Ma!". When he sees the meat he flies and lands on the human's hand.
We give him a bit of meat and we step back even more.
‎‎This is how we make it go outside.
(? - missing, clearly means something like "That is how we teach it")
This is how we make it go outside.
When it has become accustomed to the bait (lure) it no longer fears its master.
Next we bring it hunting.
When it catches game, we don't give it meat.
The longer it's hungry the more it hunts.
(? - missing)
When the hunt is over, we bring the bird back to the house and we give it a small piece of meat.
We also tame saker falcolns in this same way.
But the saker falcoln doesn't land in trees.
They make nests in boulders, on rocks and in places that are difficult to access.
We do not put a slip knot [over its head], we capture it with the help of bait (a lure).
We make a loop of horsehair around a tame partridge connected to its master by a string.
We bring the partridge to a deserted spot.
The partridge's master hides.
When a sparrowhawk sees the partridge
It throws itself on it
and sinks its claws into it.
When its feet are in the loop, it struggles and tightens it [the loop].
Then the owner of the partridge captures the sparrowhawk.
